lines.text:
[to Queen Elizabeth I]
I might have known you'd come to gloat like this - stealthily, under cover of night.
You were born too close to my throne.
I have loved as a woman loves, lost as a woman loses... My son shall sit on the throne! My son shall rule England! Still, still, I win!
Rebellion! How I hate that word!

[to Bothwell]
What's my throne? I'd put a torch to it for any one of the days with you.
I have only followed my conscience.
War! Is that all you men know?
Someday you'll meet a man who won't take no for an answer.
Dark or bright, I'll always follow your star, Mary.
You never can count on a woman. Marry her, and she turns to ice.

[to Mary]
You're the Queen of Scotland, and you've let the woman in you take your senses!
